Cielo was then left in charge of all the household expenses and so she had to improve her income in order to have enough money to provide her three children with a better quality of life.  She started selling hardware products as well as stationery products, taking advantage of the rise in construction work in her area.  Now, thanks to her hardware sales, she has managed to provide her children with access to a better quality education and her household has better financial opportunities for making progress.  Her biggest dream is to provide her children with access to a university education and so she is looking to increase her sales.  She is requesting a loan so that she can buy stationery and hardware products that she does not currently sell in her business so that she can offer her customers a wider range of products and increase her sales.  This will enable her to make better income for her household and her children will have the opportunity to enjoy a university education which will allow them to make progress in life.  Cielo's dream is to have larger premises for her business where she can arrange everything better and where she can create jobs for people who need them most.

loans.use: to buy stationery and hardware products that she currently doesn't sell in her business so that she can offer her customers more products and increase her sales

loans.name: Roquesa

texts.en:
Roquesa works hard to support her family. Roquesa is married and has a business selling used cloth in the Philippines. Roquesa requested a 30,000-Philippine-peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to buy additional bundles of used clothing to sell.

Roquesa has been in this business for 40 years now. In the future, Roquesa would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional bundles of used clothing to sell

loans.name: Esmeralda

texts.es: Esmeralda es soltera y trabaja para una empresa de seguridad, tiene tiempo que ya se independizo de sus padres, actualmente esta pagando su casa, y necesita la construcción de la barda ya que quiere proteger su vivienda al igual que garantizar el resguardo de su integridad física en el interior de su casa, pues se vive mucha inseguridad en este municipio, por lo que le dará mayor tranquilidad.
texts.en: Esmeralda is single and works for a security firm.  She started living independently from her parents some time ago and is currently paying for her house.  She needs to build a perimeter wall as she would like to protect her home as well as safeguard her personal safety inside her home because there is a lot of crime in this town.  This will give her greater peace of mind.

loans.use: to build a perimeter wall

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to invest in fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en: Lilia is 63 years old and married; she has eight children. She is from Tabid, Misamis Occidental. Lilia used her last loan to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Her business has grown and become successful. Now, she's taking a new loan to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Positively, she hopes to be able to continue to grow her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Sohieng

texts.en:
Sohieng (in the picture), age 30, sells grocery items at home. Her husband, Vuthy, age 41, is a rice farmer and raises cows at home. They have been married since 2000 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two are in school and another one is still young.  

Sohieng’s family lives in a village across the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Sohieng is asking for a loan in the amount of $1,500 to buy additional grocery items for resale. She will use a part of the loan to build a shelter where her husband raises cows.

loans.use: to buy additional grocery items for resale and build a shelter where her husband raises cows

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en:
Rosalina is 52 years old and married with 2 children.  Rosalina works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy more stock of items to sell.

Rosalina has borrowed and repaid 20 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 13 years and also earns an income from pig fattening.

Rosalina aspires to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell

loans.name: Leope

texts.en:
Leope works hard to support her family. Leope is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines.  She requested a 15,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients and stock for her food vending business. Leope has been in this business for 3 years now.

In the future, Leope would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients and stock for her food vending business

loans.name: Carlita

texts.en:
Carlita is 52 years old and married with 2 children. She earns a living by raising livestock in the Philippines. Carlita is borrowing 30,000 PHP through NWTF to buy more livestock to raise.

Carlita has been raising livestock for 2 years and also earns additional income from food vending and a sari-sari (convenience) store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more livestock to raise

loans.name: Say

texts.en:
Say, aged 40, is a farmer who lives with her spouse and three school-aged children in Ornlong Veng district. She has been doing a farming business together with her husband for almost five years and makes in the vicinity of 4.50 USD per day. Earnings from the business goes for daily food and allowances for her children. Aside from farm work, Say owns and manages a general store selling various kinds of home products for more income. 

Say has a strong determination to improve her farming practices and increase her output, which is why she is now asking for a loan of 4,000,000 KHR to purchase fertilizers and pesticides used in farming.  With the amount left, she will purchase spices, canned products, personal care products and other home use products to sell in her store. This will help Say maintain good profits from her two businesses. Say desires to provide all of her children with a higher education, so they might have better jobs and futures.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pesticides used in farming

loans.name: Elyne

texts.en: Elyne is married with four children. She is 35 years old and lives in the Philippines. Elyne is a farmer and she operates a banana production to earn a living. She has been doing this for seven years and every month she earn 5,000 PHP from this work. She has requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Elyne joined GDMPC in 2011. In the future, Elyne hopes to improve/expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer such as manure.

loans.name: Felecita

texts.en:
Felelcita is married and has four children none of whom is below the age of 15 years. She lives with her family in a four-bedroom house located at GTHS Bamenda quarters of the North West Region of Cameroon.

She has faced enormous challenges in life such as illiteracy since she dropped out of school, the death of her father and sister who were both offering her a helping hand in her little endeavors, the lack of start-up capital, and low income leaving her children lacking a means of proper education and medical care. Learning about the GHAPE programm she decided to join it as she saw hope in their package which includes convenient repayment modules, low interest and adequate business techniques training.

With this loan she plans buy wood for fuel for sale, chicks for poultry, maize and some vegetable seed to plant in her farm, some piglets for her piggery and animal feed for both the pigs and fowls. This activity will succeed because of the ever-growing demand  for wood to use as fuel in the urban town of Bamenda, high demand for poultry products and also pork from within and without Bamenda. Again the high influx of people into the city of Bamenda warrants many mouths to feed, thus the need also for more farming activity, the reason why she is also in farming. Moreover, the by-products of the fowls and pigs will be used as fertilizer in her farm thus reducing cost of buying fertilizer. This activity will help the community in that it will reduce the long distance mostly women go in search of fuel wood and increase the availability of protein products on residents' tables.

loans.use: to pay for  seeds, wood for fuel, chicks, piglets and feed

loans.name: Ashur Mansur

texts.en:
Ashur Mansur is a young and purposeful man. He is good-looking, clever and smart. Some years ago he had a very difficult life. He went to Russia to find a job but he didn’t find any job. Ashur returned to home and began an agriculture business. For more than five years, he has been busy with growing potatoes. His potatoes are very tasty and all cooks want to prepare food from such potatoes. His produce finds many customers in the local market. 

Ashur's wife helps him in his business. They have a child and love him very much. Ashur wants to develop his business and that’s why he needs your help. He is asking for a loan to buy mineral fertilizers and cattle. He awaits your help.

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizers and cattle

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela is a farmer in Nkubu area of Central Kenya and has been in active farming for thirteen successive years, running the farm with one farmhand. She produces milk, coffee, tea, fruit and vegetables. She runs a grocery retail business with her products being sourced from her farm and other farms. She is married with three children aged 13, 8 and 4 years old.

Pamela has made a loan request for 60,000 KES from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to help her construct a zero grazing unit at 30,000 KES and buy dairy goats for 30,000 KES. She says the income will go into educating her children.

She however laments poor market prices locally  and high cost of labour offered by farmhands.

loans.use: To construct a zero grazing unit and buy dairy goats

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en:
Geraldine is from Tabid, Ozamis City, in the Philippines. She is 39 years old, married and has three children. 

To make a living, Geraldine runs a general store, selling a variety of food and household products in the local community. Geraldine has been running her business for seven years and earns 3,800 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month.

Geraldine is requesting a loan of 4,500 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee. In 2008, Geraldine joined the Gata Daku Multi-purpose Cooperative (GDMPC). She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to create savings for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase additional products like canned goods, noodles, sugar and coffee

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a 43-year-old married woman who is responsible for six children, all in school. Her husband earns a living by operating a cafe, while she is engaged in selling firewood. She has been in this business for over eight years. Halima is an industrious woman who always wants to try whenever an opportunity arises.

Due to lack of enough capital, Halima is requesting a loan to buy stock of firewood for sale. She hopes that the loan will help her business to grow. Thanks to her efforts, she has been able to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy stock of firewood for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of dried fish, squid and shrimp to re-sell

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en: Conchita, 58, is a widow with four children residing at Pan-ay Diot, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. She used her last loan to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Her business is successful, and she's taking out a new loan to purchase fertilizers such as manure. In the future she hopes to be able to grow her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Chepkwony

texts.en:
Chepkwony is aged 33 and married with three children, aged between ten and four years old. He has been in farming for ten years and sells his farm produce of milk to the local Brookside Dairies and at the market where he also runs a retail shop business.

Chepkwony has requested a loan of 40,000 KES to buy a chuff cutter which will help in feeding his dairy cows and reduce the wastage of animal feeds. He adds that the additional income will improve the living standards of family.

Chepkwony says his main challenge is usually the fluctuation of farm produce prices and also advocates that Juhudi Kilimo intensifies the training for farming to equip farmers with better skills.

loans.use: To purchase a chuff cutter (to cut fodder)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
A married man with a lot of dynamism, Emmanuel has three children with two below the age of 15 years. He lives in the Upper GTTC neighborhood of Nkwen- Bamenda, North West Region of Cameroon. He and the family are living in a three-room apartment with an average of two person per room. 

It has not been easy for him and his family due to their poverty. He has encountered some difficulties in life such as being unable to take  care of his family, buy his children’s medication, pay for their education and other life circumstances until he joined GHAPE in 2007. He has taken out and successful repaid his loan three times. His business is located in Kedjom Keku where he sells animal feed and piglets. He also intends to expand his business in the near future.

He says that with the loan, he will buy more stocks of animal feed for piglets. This is because of the high demand for feed in the region due to the increase in animal farming  in Bamenda and Kedjom Keku in particular. He will also  purchase pigs and  piglets. He will also expand the business and the profit will be used to cater for his family. He believes his business will succeed because of good marketing, a good business site, regular customers, regular supplies and because he produces good piglets. His activity will help the community because it will relieve them from the stress of moving to distant places in search of feed and piglets. Also the activity will employed some of the youth. He says GHAPE loans are preferable because of the low interest rate, convenient time of payment, and marketing education on how to target potential customers before loan disbursement.

loans.use: to pay for piglets and animal feed

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
This is Teresita, a mother of three who lives in Quezon City, the Philippines. She previously accessed an 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) loan that she utilized to buy additional car accessories and tires for her car wash business. Her earnings were a big help for her family's personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 12,000 PHP loan that she will use to buy more materials needed in her business. Her profits will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial support with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Teresita dreams of opening another car wash in another area. She wants her children to become college graduates. She never fails to attend the fellowship* meeting every week as it inspires her to become a better person by studying the word of God and sharing His goodness with everyone.
  
* All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stocks of car accessories and other products needed for her car wash business

loans.name: Asifiwe Yesu Group

texts.fr: La cliente Kavira est présidente d’un groupe de crédit  Asifiwe Yesu, âgée de 38 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 7 jeunes enfants. Son mari est un chauffeur. La cliente est vendeuse d’huile de palme. Elle commença son entreprise avec le crédit de l’IMF Hekima vers les années 2005. Actuellement, elle est au 24e cycle de crédit. Elle a tiré plus d’avantages dans le programme de microcrédit de Hekima, dit-elle. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec  6 fus d’huile de palme. Dans les jours à venir, elle ambitionne acheter un véhicule pour son mari. Ainsi, elle remercie Hekima pour son appui  et autonomisation des petits entrepreneurs femmes
texts.en: Our customer Kavira, 38 years old, is the leader  of the Asifiwe Yesu loan group. She is married and the mother of seven young children. Her husband is a driver. Kavira sells palm oil. She launched he business with a loan from IMF Hekima around 2005. At present, she is on her 24th loan cycle. She says that she has benefited a lot from the Hekima microloan program. This new loan will allow her to stock up by buying six casks of palm oil. In the future, her goal is to buy a car for her husband. She thanks Hekima for its support and for helping small business run by women become independent.

loans.use: to buy six casks of palm oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann is a mother of one child aged two years and is a farmer in Nkubu, where she has been in farming for five years. Farming is her main source of income for meeting the family's basic needs, but she also runs a boutique shop. Her farm produces mainly milk, tea and fruit. 

Ann has made a loan request amounting to 60,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to buy iron sheets to construct a dairy unit (for 40,000 KES) and water pipes which she will use to install an irrigation system in her farm. 

Ann says poor milk prices, pests and diseases are the major challenges she faces.

loans.use: To construct a dairy unit and buy irrigation water pipes

loans.name: Rahimakhon

texts.en:
Rahimakhon is a woman who likes to work very hard. She has a very difficult life as her husband went to Russia and she is the lone food provider for the family. She has five children and Rahimakhon must comfort them with all modern conveniences. 

Some months ago she heard about a course about organizing one's own business. Rahimakhon took this course and now wants to organize her business. As she likes animals she decided to try animal husbandry. She is asking for a loan to buy cattle. She needs your help. Rahimakhon would be happy if you will help her.

loans.use: To buy cattle for starting a business

loans.name: Silika

texts.en:
Silika is a 34-year-old landlady in Mombasa. She is a married mother of three children. She has been a landlady for the past eleven years and she is doing great. She also keeps poultry to supplement her income.

This is Silika’s second loan from KADET Ltd. She plans to renovate her rental houses. She will use the anticipated profits to build more houses for rent and to educate her children. 

She hopes to buy more land to build more rental houses.

loans.use: to renovate her rental houses.

loans.name: Manolita

texts.en:
Manolita is 68 years old and married with three children. She lives in Tuyabang Bajo, Oroquieta City. 

To earn a living, Manolita has a hog fattening business. She has had this business for six years. Each month, she earns approximately 3,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP). She has requested a loan of 14,900 PHP to purchase feed & piglets. Manolita has been a member of PMPC for six years. 

In the future, Manolita hopes to own a piggery.

loans.use: to purchase feed & piglets

loans.name: Danny

texts.en:
Danny is 30 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married and has two children. Danny has a food/retail shop or sari-sari store that sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products & beverages. He has had this business for six years. 

He requested a loan of 5,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks & beverages. Danny has been a member of HSPFI since 2012. In the future, Danny hopes to improve his business for the education of his children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Khen

texts.en:
Khen, age 55, lives in a village about fifteen Kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She is a widowed mother with one daughter who is a garment worker. 

Khen is a rice farmer. She is asking for a loan of $300 to buy seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her rice farm and to pay for plowing fees.   

In the photo, you can see Khen at home, not at the farm.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her rice farm and to pay for plowing fees.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a very enterprising woman who operates her food-selling business. Halima has already received and successfully repaid one loan, and now requires a new loan in order to buy bales of wheat flour, sugar, and cooking oil. In the future, Halima plans to open a cafe. 

She thanks you for your support. She says that since the previous loan, her living standards have improved and that she has been able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy bales of wheat flour, sugar, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
This is Angelina. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her child and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 12,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and educational expenses of her child. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Angelina hopes her business grows and becomes a mini-grocery in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Tri

texts.en:
Tri (who is in the photo) is 24. He works for a printing shop. His wife, Monyneath, age 20, is a hairdresser. She does not have her own hair salon; she is hired and gets paid with fees. They just have one young daughter and live in a village about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Tri is asking for a loan of $1,000 to buy a motorbike for commuting. Tri and his wife work at Phnom Penh, and they rent a portion of a house. With a motorbike, which he will buy with the money from the loan, he will be able to visit his homeland on the weekends and holidays.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Khoun

texts.en:
Khoun is 24 years of age and married, residing in Ornlong Veng district, Oddar Meanchey province. She happily lives there with her spouse and two lovely young kids. Khoun and her husband work in the same type of business, cultivating rice crops for both sustenance and for sale. She has been doing this for 11 years and it is the sole source of family income. Khoun would like to purchase and install some pigs to fatten in order to generate additional income and satisfy her basic living needs.

As of now, Khoun wants a loan of USD 700 to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farming business, and to purchase pigs to fatten and eventually sell. She believes that the loan will have a positive impact toward attaining her goal. Khoun and her spouse will try to work harder for their children’s future education.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticides for her farming business, and to purchase pigs to fatten and sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock of coconut for making copra (the dried meat of the coconut).

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson is a farmer in his rural area in Nkubu, Central Kenya. He produces maize, tea, coffee, fruits and vegetables which are partly consumed by the family and also sold to meet other needs. He also runs a boutique and a salon business in the local market. He is married with three children aged 17,15 and seven years.

Johnson has requested a loan of 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo which he plans to use to buy a water tank and water pipes to install an irrigation system in his farming business. He says his focus is to use the additional income and build a decent residential house for his family.

Johnson however says high costs of farm inputs remain the major challenge.

loans.use: To buy a water tank and water pipes.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
This is Edna, resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is married to Edgardo, her business partner, and is the mother of a child. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 
                            
Edna operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Edna hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Kutfiddin

texts.en: 20 years ago a man by name Kutfiddin began his own business. Now he is a good businessman. His business of vegetables and corn is growing. His experiences help him to be successful in business and he loves his work. His goods have many customers in the local market. He has a friendly family. His 4 children love him very much. Kutfiddin wants to develop his business. He is asking for a loan to buy mineral fertilizers for land where he works. He waits your help and mercy. Please help him.

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Sreymom

texts.en:
Sreymom, age 32, sells grocery items from home. Her husband, Sopheaktra, age 30, is in the air force. They have been married for nine years and have two children who are in school, one son and one daughter.   

Sreymom’s family lives in a suburb of Phnom Penh. She wants to earn extra income by renting space in her house. And Sreymom is now in the process of building six rooms to rent, but some are not finished yet. 

Hence, she has decided to ask for a loan for an amount of $1,500 in order to finish the work.

loans.use: To build rooms to rent.

loans.name: Ley's Group

texts.en:
Ley is aged 58 years old and a mother of six children. Three of them are still dependent on her and the others are working at the factory in Thailand. To overcome the family's hardship, she has been farming on one-hectare of farmland as the primary source of income. Additionally, she also raises chickens and works for others for a fee. These are the businesses that she and her husband have been doing for 15 years. 

The main problem for her family is the flood last year which affected her crop yield. In 2011, Ley joined VisionFund as a first-cycle client, and successfully paid back the loan. This stablized her family's living conditions and helped them with the difficult situation. She is now happily in applying for a new loan with VisionFund with other two members. She and one member are applying for 500,000 KHR each while another one is requesting for 1,000,000 KHR. As the group leader, she will use the portion of her loan to buy more chickens and feed for them. She hopes to raise a lot of chicken so that she can earn more money to keep improving her living standards.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and chicken feed.

location.town: Banteay Meanchey Province, Mongkul Borey District

loans.name: Hean's Group

texts.en:
Hean, aged 42, is living in the rural area of the Ek Phnom district of Battambang province, Cambodia. She is married and has four children, two (one daughter and one son) of whom are dependent on her and in school. Hean has been in fishing for five years, and her husband works as a security guard to earn extra income. They can earn about KHR 24,600 per day from their current businesses to meet family’s needs.

Hean has been with VisionFund for five loan cycles, while the other group member has been with VisionFund for six cycles. Her group consists of two female members. Now Hean is requesting a new loan with VisionFund of KHR1,000,000. As the group leader, she is going to use her portion to buy more fish for selling. She hopes this will enable her to live with a better lifestyle and keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy more fish for selling.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is 54 years old. She is a charcoal dealer in Miritini, Mombasa. She is a married mother of four children. She buys and sells charcoal to the residents of Miritini, a business she has done for the past four years. She is doing great.

This is her second borrowing from KADET LTD to finance her business. She plans to purchase more sacks of charcoal with the loan. She will use the proceeds to educate her children and repay her loan. 

She hopes to have a more profitable business.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of charcoal  for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a rickshaw body for rickshaw transport business.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is a farmer in the Nkubu area of Central Kenya. He is aged 52 and married with five children who are adults, save for the last three who are still schooling. His 25 years in active farming has seen him educate his first two children. His farm is currently producing maize, fruits, vegetables and poultry products.

Jackson has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to buy dairy goats. He adds he has resorted to dairy goat farming because of harsh weather conditions that are rather hostile for dairy cows, and because of common poultry diseases which lead to huge losses of poultry flocks during outbreaks. However, he hopes to raise enough income to educate the last three children.

Jackson points at high efficiency in loan processing by Juhudi Kilimo as a major step in improving the lives of small-scale farmers.

loans.use: To buy dairy goats.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy plants to replant his crop and pay for labor to clear, prune, and harvest the fields.

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina is married and has six children. The entire family is living in a five room house at the Ndamukong quarters of Nkwen Bamenda in the northwest Region of Cameroon.  Mama has faced the problem of inadequate capital, poverty within the family cycle, sudden death amongst family members, ill health and injuries as a result of accident.  Then GHAPE came to her life and changed the story.

Christina intends to use this loan to buy seedlings and chicks for her poultry farm. This will help the community to increase their food needs and thus alleviate hunger. The profits will be use to pay school fees for her children and improve the conditions of the house.  She says her business will succeed because she has been doing this activity for a very long time and people in her community will serve as a ready market for her products.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and seedlings

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en: Analyn is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 3 children. Analyn  has a food/retail shop, or sari-sari store, that sells canned goods, snacks, personal care products, home use products & beverages. She has had this business for 9  years. She requested a loan of PHP5,000  to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks & beverages. Analyn  has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Analyn hopes to improve her business for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
This is Milagros, a resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is married to Ariel, her business partner, and a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating a variety store business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.    
                         
In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns money by getting supplies in bulk at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Milagros hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her children a high-quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Jhonny

texts.en: Jhonny is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married with three children. Jhonny sells meat in the public market in his local community. He has had this business for seven years. He requested a loan for 5,000 PHP to buy more meat to re sell. Jhonny has been a member of HSPFI since 2012.  In the future,Jhonny hopes to improve his business to pay for the education of his children.

loans.use: to buy more meat to re sell.

loans.name: Essoham Group

texts.fr: Ayant en son sein treize membres, le groupe de solidarité ESSOHAM a pour présidente Yawa. Âgée de 60 ans et cultivatrice de profession, Yawa est mariée à un cultivateur et tous deux ont trois enfants qui ne sont plus scolarisés dont le premier a 38 ans et le second est âgé de 28 ans. Depuis 1985, Yawa exerce son activité de culture de maïs et d' haricot   dans la région centrale et est aidée par deux membres de sa famille. Dans le but de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille, cette maman sollicite pour sa première fois un crédit auprès de WAGES afin d’acheter quelques outils pour son travail. Comme perspectives d’avenir, elle compte augmenter sa superficie cultivable et construire un bâtiment pour sa famille. Les autres membres du groupe font aussi la culture des maïs et du haricot et veulent voir leur famille s'épanouir.
texts.en: The Essoham solidarity group has 13 members in its fold. Its leader is  Yawa. 60 years  old and a farmer by trade, Yawa is married to a farmer. They have three children who are no longer in school: the oldest is 38 years old, and the [youngest] is 28 years old. Since 1985, Yawa has been growing corn and beans in the central region. Two relatives help her in this work.  With the goal of providing for family needs, Yawa is seeking her first loan from WAGES in order to buy some work tools. For the future, she would like to expand her arable land and build a house for her family. Other group members also grow corn and bean and would like to ensure the well-being of their families.

loans.use: to buy work tools.

loans.name: Olim

texts.en: For more than 16 years, Olim has been busy in his agriculture business. He knows all aspects of his business and has a lot of friends who love him very much. Olim got a loan from Imon International organization and that loan helped him very much. Nowadays, he wants to develop his business further but lacks income. He has a large family and wants to do the best for them. With a loan, he wants to buy cattle and mineral fertilizers. Olim and his family appreciate your help and support.

loans.use: to buy mineral fertilizers and cattle.

loans.name: Thoun's Group

texts.en: Thoun is a resident from the Ek Phnom district of Battambang province, Cambodia, Thoun is 34 years old, married and has two sons, both of whom are still under her responsibility and in school. To earn a living, Thoun has been selling fried crickets and boiled eggs for five years. Her husband is a construction worker in a local area earning extra income to support their family. Together, they can earn around KHR 29,700 per day from their current business to meet their family’s needs. Thoun’s group consists of two members. She and her fellow group member have been with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund for two cycles and completely paid back all the loans. The past loans have enabled her to improve her standard of living with sufficient food and to keep her children in school. Now she is applying for a new loan with VisionFund of KHR 2,000,000. As the group leader, she is going to use to her portion to buy more crickets and eggs for selling. She plans to grow sugarcane as another source of income. In the future, she hopes to increase her family's income to improve her standard of living and keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy more crickets and eggs for selling.

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en:
This is Mylene. She previously asked for a 12,000 PHP loan that she used to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. Her earnings were a big help in paying for the education of her child and their personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for a 14,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store, the better. Having more items to sell will result in better profits. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her child. She looks forward to this financial increase with happiness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Mylene dreams of being able to see her child graduate from college. She also dreams of expanding her business someday and making it a grocery store. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. She also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products for her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy keys and tools for duplicate key-making business

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
This is Tessie. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her child and for their personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another loan, this time for 12,000 PHP, to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products to add to her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the education expenses of her child. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Tessie hopes that her business will expand and grow. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther still owns a retail shop in Mariakani. She is single. She has been running a retail shop for the past four years with great success. 

This is Esther’s second loan from KADET. She plans to purchase cooking oil, rice, baking flour, maize flour, and washing powders for her stock.

She will use the proceeds from her expanded business to buy land to build rental houses. She hopes to excel in the business.

loans.use: to purchase more sugar, rice, cooking oil, and washing detergent

loans.name: Eduarda

texts.es: La Sra. Eduarda tiene 45 años y es casada con 3 hijos que son de las edades de 27, 25 y 20 años, ella se dedica a la venta variedad de pan, roscas y empanadas en su puesto de venta que se encuentran ubicado en una zona muy concurrida de la ciudad de Cochabamba,  este préstamo es su primera secuencia dentro de la institución, la Sra. Eduarda  va a usar este préstamo para la conexión de alcantarillado para tener un baño en su domicilio, ya que esto le permitirá contar con un servicio básico en su casa y así brindar mayor comodidad a su familia, su razón para solicitar este préstamo es no cuenta con el dinero suficiente para adquirir lo necesario, la Sra. Eduarda enfrenta retos en su negocio que son la competencia, y utilizara los beneficios para revestimiento y construcción de un baño y ducha, la Sra. Eduarda se siente feliz con esta oportunidad que le brindan, ya que hará su sueño realidad que es contar con un baño terminado.
texts.en: Eduarda is forty-five, married, and has three children, who are twenty-seven-, twenty-five-, and twenty-years-old.  She earns her living selling assorted breads, ring cookies, and empanadas from her stand, which is located in a busy area in the city of Cochabamba.  This will be her first loan with this institution.  She plans to use it to add a sewer connection so she can have a bathroom in her house.  This basic service will bring more comfort to her family.  She's seeking a loan because she can't afford what she needs.  She faces challenges, like competition, in her business, so she'll use her profits to reinvest and to put in the bathroom and shower.  Eduarda is happy for the opportunity she's being given because it will fulfill her dream, which is to have a finished bathroom.

loans.use: to  pay for a sewer system connection so she can have a bathroom in her house.

loans.name: Boymat

texts.en: Boymat is the sole provider for his family. He has a very friendly family. As Boymat is very kind-hearted and glorious, his family loves him very much. Some years ago he went to Russia to find a job, but he did not find any job. He returned home and began his own business. He is busy with animal husbandry. He works hard and is a successful businessman. To Boymat, the business helps his wife and daughter. They want to develop the business, but they do not have enough income for it. He is asking for a loan to buy young cattle for developing his business. He waits your help and mercy.

loans.use: To buy young cattle for developing his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Consolee

texts.en:
Consolee is married with four children. Currently two of her children attend school, while the other two are still young to start schooling. She has spent six years in rice production. She has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers and to support labor costs to get the best harvest. Consolee plans to reinvest the profits to expand the area that she has been cultivating and also pay school fees for her children.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and support labor costs.

loans.name: Ny's Group

texts.en:
Ny is 44 years old and married, living in the rural village of Ek Phnom district of Battambang province, Cambodia. She has seven children; four daughters and three sons, five of whom are still dependent on her. Ny has been rice farming on 1.5 hectares of farmland, planting fruit, such as watermelons, and corn on one-hectare and supplements her family’s income by fishing and as a paid worker to earn extra income. She has been in these businesses for 28 years and is able to earn around 45,000 KHR per day. The main challenge of her business is low crop yields resulting from flooding. 

Ny’s group consists of two female members. She has been with VisionFund for three cycles and successfully paid back the past loans, while the other member just joined this cycle. The past loans have helped her with a better living. Now she is leading this group to apply for a loan with VisionFund. As the group leader, she is going to use her portion to buy fertilizers and rice seeds for her farmland. She hopes this loan will enable her family to make more income to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and rice seeds for her farmland

loans.name: Prich

texts.en:
Prich is 32 years old and a loving mother, who is responsible for three school-age children. She was born on the family farm and got a low level of education due to the family’s financial constraints. Prich doesn’t want her children to follow her path of life, so she will strive to work hard to avoid their lack of education. Prich has been involved in the business of raising pigs and cultivating agricultural crops as the major source of the family’s income. With her many years of experience and help from her husband, Prich is able to stabilize her current businesses and make consistent profits for her children’s education. 

Prich would like to borrow her first cycle loan from lenders to pay for labor costs incurred in transplanting rice and purchase additional piglets to raise. She believes that through her hardships, patience, and the help of the loan, she will be able to achieve her desire and experience a quality life someday.

loans.use: to pay for labor costs incurred in transplanting rice and purchase additional piglets to raise.

loans.name: Viateur

texts.en:
Viateur is married with three children aged between three and nine. His wife is a farmer. He has been a rice farmer for four years. He would like to get this Kiva loan to buy fertilizers and to support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been using to get more output and make savings. In the future he would like to own a machine for cultivation.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and support labor costs.

loans.name: Tuinuwane Group

texts.fr: La cliente Katungu est un entrepreneur ambitieux, présidente du groupe de crédit Tuinuane, âgée de 42 ans, mère de 5 jeunes enfants. Son mari est infirmier. Elle est vendeuse des épices (tomates, arachides, oignons, tangausi, etc.) Elle commença son business avec son fonds propre reçu de son mari, il ya environs 4 ans. Elle bénéficia de crédit de l’IMF Hekima vers les années 2010. Elle installe ses produits au marché central de Virunga. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner avec 4 bidons d’huile végétale, tangausi, tomates, etc. En plus, elle ambitionne augmenter son épargne enfin d’ouvrir d’autres activités génératrices de revenu. Les bénéfices de son activité lui permettent de payer aisement les frais scolaires, la nourriture,les soins médicaux, etc., pour sa famille. Ainsi, elle remercie Hekima pour son appui et autonomisation des petits entrepreneurs femmes.
texts.en:
The client, Katungu, is an ambitious entrepreneur and the president of the loan group Tuinuane. She is 42 years old and has 5 young children. Her husband is a nurse. 

She sells spices (tomatoes, peanuts, onions, ginger, etc.). She started her business about 4 years ago with money she received from her husband. IMF Hekima granted her a loan around 2010. 

She sells her products in the central market of Virunga. This new loan will help her buy 4 cans of vegetable oil, ginger, tomatoes, etc. In addition, she would like to increase her savings so that she can start working on other revenue-generating activities. The profits from her business help her easily pay for school fees, food, medical care, etc. for the family. 

She thanks Hekima for their support of female small business owners.

loans.use: to buy 4 cans of vegetable oil, ginger, tomatoes, etc.

loans.name: Antonina

texts.en:
Antonina is a widow and farmer in Kitale where she lives and also has been practicing farming for 28 years and selling her produce of milk, maize, beans, and vegetables to the local market. She has seven adult children.

Antonina has requested a loan of 52,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. She hopes to raise more income to meet her family's basic needs and buy two better breeds of dairy cows in five years.

Antonina says seasonal weather changes and lack of farming capital spell the greatest challenge in farming.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Lidao Group

texts.fr: Cultivateur de profession, Kondébalo est le Président de l’Association LIDAO composé de 09 membres. Âgé de 48 ans, Kondébalo est marié à une revendeuse et est père de famille de trois enfants tous scolarisés actuellement. L’ainé est âgé de 14 ans et le plus jeune a 08 ans. L’activité de Kondébalo se porte principalement sur la culture du maïs et ceci depuis trente ans. Il est aidé dans l’exerce de ses fonctions par un membre de sa famille. Pour augmenter sa production, il sollicite un crédit auprès de WAGES pour l’achat des semences nécessaire à son activité. Ainsi ces revenus supplémentaires lui serviront à ouvrir une boutique et construire un logement. Aussi, il compte pour l’avenir augmenter ses superficies cultivables et subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. La culture du maïs  constitue l’activité des autres membres du groupement.
texts.en:
Kondébalo, a farmer, is the president of the LIDAO association, which is composed of nine members. Kondébalo, age 48, is a married father of three children aged 8 to 14 who all go to school. His wife is a reseller. 

Kondébalo’s farming activity has been focused primarily on maize for thirty years. A family member helps him in his work. 

Hoping to increase his yield, he is seeking a loan from WAGES to buy seeds. The extra revenue will allow him to open a shop and build a house. In the long run, he wants to expand his farmable area and support his family’s needs. 

The other group members are maize farmers as well.

loans.use: to buy seeds and farming tools.

loans.name: Chreng's Group

texts.en:
Chreng is from Sangke district in Battambang province, Cambodia. She is 36 years old and has six children, two of whom are in her burden. She has been involved in raising ducks for six years to support her family. To meet her family's needs, she is able to earn around 38,900 Cambodian riels (KHR) per day from her current business. 

Chreng’s group consists of three members. She has been with VisionFund for five cycles and completely paid back the past loans while the other members have been with VisionFund for one to two cycles. The past loans have helped her with a living better. Now she is applying for a loan of KHR 1,400,000. As the group leader, she is going to use her portion to buy more ducks for raising. In the future, she hopes to increase her income from her current business so as to make a standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more ducks for raising

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 26 years old. He is single and has been in business for six years with a monthly income of KES 43,000. He will use the loan to expand the butchery by buying more meat for sale. The anticipated profits will be used to grow the business.

This is his second loan from KADET LTD and he has completely repaid his previous loan successfully. His hopes and dreams are to expand the business and be big, buy a piece of land and build, and then get married and raise a family.

loans.use: to buy more meat to sell.

loans.name: Wilson

texts.es: Wilson de 50 años de edad vive con su esposa y sus 2 hijos en las edades de 3 y 17  en la ciudad de Cartagena, lugar ubicado a orillas del Mar Caribe,  uno de los sitios turísticos mas hermosos de Colombia y muy reconocido, pues   tiene una de las principales bases navales del país y  por su patrimonio histórico-artístico, que abarca de vestigios de época cartaginesa, romana, bizantina, edificaciones de carácter militar de época moderna y contemporánea, así como también edificios neoclásicos y modernistas. Allí en este fantástico lugar y de manera modesta, tiene su propio negocio de telecomunicaciones, donde también vende cervezas, refrescos,  golosinas, dulces y comestibles procesados industrialmente. Su negocio lo inició desde hace 2 años cuando empezó vendiendo llamadas celulares, bajo la sombra de un árbol ubicado cerca de su casa. Todo esto con el fin de generar ingresos, para lograr el sostenimiento de su familia; poco a poco su negocio fue creciendo,  pues como buen observador, identificó un gran potencial de transeúntes, que pudieran ser parte de su clientela como con el tiempo lo logró y para ellos agregó dulcería, productos comestibles y bebidas con los que ganó dinero, ahorró y se trasladó a su casa, donde  ubicó  dos mesas con vitrinas y aprovechando la nueva nevera familiar, agregó refrescos y bebidas. Hoy está muy entusiasmado con ese cambio y con su disciplina de ahorro, compró un enfriador,  ya que la nevera familiar no respondía a su crecimiento. En la actualidad además de todos los anteriores productos, también vende lácteos y calzado, además de mercancías variadas, que va registrando en los pedidos   de su clientela. En la medida en que ha ido creciendo el negocio de Wilson,  su capital de trabajo se torna insuficiente,  para responder a la demanda del mercado, esta es la razón por la cual acude a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el cual comprará víveres, abarrotes, estantería metálica, para ira asimilando su negocio a una tienda, donde comercialice los productos de la canasta familiar, que son de alto consumo entre su potencial clientela. Así mismo adecuará el techo en la terraza de su casa, para proteger a su clientela del incesante sol del caribe y bajar la temperatura del lugar donde ella trabaja, proporcionándole   un poco de sombra a su negocio y con ello proporcionar un mejor estar a todos.
texts.en:
Wilson, age 50, lives with his wife and two children, ages 3 and 17.  They live in the beautiful city of Cartagena, which is located on the shores of the Caribbean Sea.  It is one of Colombia’s best-known tourist sites because it has one of the country’s main naval bases and its historical-artistic heritage encompasses Carthaginian, Roman and Byzantine military styles from both modern and contemporary ages as well as neo-classical and modern buildings.

It is in this fantastic place that he has his own modest telecommunications business.  He also sells beer, soft drinks, sweets, candies, and processed foods there.  He started his business two years ago when he started to sell cell phone services beneath the shade of a tree that is close to his house.
He does all of this in order to generate income to support his family.  Little by little his business has been growing.  As a good observer, he identified a great potential from passers-by who could be part of his clientele.  In time he achieved that, and he added candy, food, and drinks for his customers.  He earned money from them, saved, and moved to his house.  He set up two tables with display cases.  He took advantage of the family refrigerator and added soda and drinks.

He is now very enthusiastic about this change. He saved with discipline, and he bought a cooler because the family refrigerator could not keep up with his growth.  In addition to all of the previous products, he now sells dairy products, shoes, and various merchandise ordered by his customers.

As long as Wilson’s business has been growing, he has not had enough working capital to respond to the market demand.  That is the reason that he turns to a Kiva loan, his first loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  He will use the loan to buy supplies, groceries, and a metal shelf in order to adapt his business to become a store.  In the store he will sells basic needs products that are consumed a lot by his potential clientele.

He will also fix the roof of the terrace of his house in order to protect his customers from the incessant Caribean sun and to lower the temperature of the place where he works.  This will provide a bit of shade for his business, which will improve everyone's well-being.

loans.use: to buy supplies, groceries, and a metal shelf, and to  adapt the roof of his terrace.

loans.name: Marie Josee

texts.en:
Marie Josee is married with one child who is 22 years old. She has spent two years in rice production. She has requested a Kiva loan to buy more fertilizers and to support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, she plans to pay school fees for her child.

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and support labor costs.

loans.name: Emiliana

texts.es: Emiliana de 35 años de edad vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos en las edades de 2 a 9 años  en la ciudad de Cartagena, lugar ubicado a orillas del Mar Caribe,  uno de los sitios turísticos mas hermosos de Colombia y muy reconocido, pues   tiene una de las principales bases navales del país y  por su patrimonio histórico-artístico, que abarca de vestigios de época cartaginesa, romana, bizantina, edificaciones de carácter militar de época moderna y contemporánea, así como también edificios neoclásicos y modernistas. Allí en este fantástico lugar y de manera modesta, desempeña su actividad comercial, pues es propietaria de un negocio de variedades, donde vende cosméticos y perfumería;  cuando inició su negocio lo hizo vendiendo víveres, que distribuía en barrios diversos de Cartagena,  entre tenderos y negociantes  al detalle. Posteriormente dejó de viajar para traer esa mercancía y se dedicó a la venta de cosméticos, accesorios, perfumería,mediante guias especializadas, los cuales hoy distribuye a crédito, con plazos semanales, mensuales y en quincenas, de acuerdo a las posibilidades de sus clientes. Sus principales clientes lo conforman los hombres, pues está enfocada en esa línea, que le deja una importante rentabilidad. Su meta es abonarle a la calidad de vida de su familia y por eso se esmera en la búsqueda de productos que al  venderlos  le proporciones una rentabilidad amplia y una rotación permanente de su capital. En la actualidad aspira a recuperar el mercado de víveres, que  representa para su negocio, mayores utilidades pero su capital de trabajo es insuficiente, para comprar en mayor volumen, ganar descuentos y hacer una oferta atractiva para sus clientes. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará arroz, aceite, legumbres, enlatados, embutidos, para venderlo en pequeños volúmenes, en tanto a que sus clientes lo ofrezcan al detalle y todos  lograr ganar en la cadena de comercialización.
texts.en:
Emiliana, 35, lives with her husband and three children whose ages range from 2 to 9 years in the city of Cartagena, located on the shores of the Caribbean Sea, one of Colombia’s best-known tourist sites because it has one of the country’s main naval bases and its historical-artistic heritage encompasses Carthaginian, Roman and Byzantine military styles from both modern and contemporary ages as well as neo-classical and modern buildings.

There in that fantastic place in a modest way she carries out her commercial activity since she owns a variety store where she sells cosmetics and perfumery.  When she started her business it was selling foodstuffs in various neighborhoods in Cartagena among shop owners and retailers.  Later on she stopped traveling to bring that kind of merchandise and started selling cosmetics, accessories and perfumery via catalogue which at present she sells on credit with weekly, monthly and bi-weekly payment plans according to her customers’ ability to pay.

Men are her main customers since she focuses on men’s products which are quite profitable.  Her goal is to increase her family’s quality of life which is why she strives to find products that upon sale produce the highest profits and a permanent capital turnover.

She is currently thinking about restarting the grocery business which will mean more business profits but her working capital is insufficient to start to buy in large volume to earn discounts and have attractive offers for her customers.  This is why she’s turning to a Kiva loan, the first financing from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo that she’ll use to buy rice, oil, legumes, canned goods and cured meats to sell in small amounts to customers who will resell at retail all of them profiting from the sales chain.

loans.use: to buy merchandise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy materials for a small wall and to buy doors.

loans.name: Francois

texts.en:
Francois is married and has four children, aged one to eleven years old. His wife is a farmer. He has been a rice farmer for four years. He would like to get this Kiva loan to buy fertilizers and to support labor costs to get the best harvest. With the profits, he plans to expand the area he has been farming to get more output and be able to save. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and support labor costs.

loans.name: Taria

texts.en:
Taria is has been in farming for over 30 years in her rural home in Kitale, Western Kenya, where she lives with her  husband and three adult children. Her farm produces milk, maize, and beans for the local market. She reiterates she fully depends on farming income for her family upkeep.

Taria has requested a loan of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. She says this will boost her income to adequately meet the family's needs. She also plans to improve the quality of her breeds in future.

Taria says the major challenge is that of feed, which is quite expensive, especially during dry seasons.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Mzevinar

texts.en:
Mzevinar is 47 years old. She lives in a small village of Lanchkhuti District with her husband, Avtandil. They earn their living through agriculture. They have 18 beehives with bee colonies. They produce honey and sell it in nearby villages. Mzevinar and Avtandil also have a citrus garden and a plot of land where they grow maize and nuts. They work hard on their plot during the spring and summer seasons to get a good harvest. They sell their harvested products in the local open market. The total average monthly income of the family is 500 Lari.

Mzevinar requested a loan to purchase feed for the bees. Mzevinar and Avtandil will be able to produce and sell more honey. This will increase the income of the family. With increased income they will be able to reinvest in the family agricultural business in order to expand it and make it more profitable.

loans.use: to purchase feed for her bees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizer for his coffee farm.

loans.name: Melida

texts.es: Melida de 44 años de edad vive con su esposo y sus 4 hijos en las edades de 6 a 24 años en la ciudad de Cartagena, lugar ubicado a orillas del Mar Caribe, uno de los sitios turísticos mas hermosos de Colombia y muy reconocido, pues   tiene una de las principales bases navales del país y  por su patrimonio histórico-artístico, que abarca de vestigios de época cartaginesa, romana, bizantina, edificaciones de carácter militar de época moderna y contemporánea, así como también edificios neoclásicos y modernistas. Allí en este fantástico lugar y de manera modesta tiene su tienda de abarrotes, refrescos, bebidas, ranchos, víveres y enlatados. Adicionalmente en su negocio ha incluido útiles de papelería, cosméticos, accesorios femeninos y otras mercancías de muy buena rotación, que complementan el  grueso de sus ventas al detalle, aumentan sus ingresos y ayudan a rotar frecuentemente su capital.  Cuando Melida  decidió desarrollar su idea emprendedora e independiente, lo hizo después de una experiencia que tuvo con su esposo, en una empresa donde vendían cueros y una vez quedaron desempleados, decidieron aprovechar el útil conocimiento de las estrategias de ventas, para emprender su propia aventura de negocio y generar sus propios empleos independientes. Así fue como empezó la tienda, pues esta pareja,  deseaba gestionar ingresos suficientes, que beneficiaran a su familia,  primero vendiendo unos  pocos productos y adicionando cada vez mas otros nuevos,  hasta lograr diversificar  como hasta hoy lo han logrado, porque también ofrecen mercancía a través de guías especializadas, especialmente productos de belleza. Su mayor desafío es no tener un capital de trabajo suficiente, para implementar una estrategia mercadológica, que le permita impactar con precios, promociones y productos, que sus clientes piden constantemente y muchas veces su negocio no soporta esta rotación, dejando insatisfechos a otros. Esta es la razón por la cual acuden a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprarán víveres, abarrotes, cárnicos, enlatados, lácteos y productos de belleza que ofrece su revista con descuentos especiales. Con esta inversión planea aumentar sus ingresos, ofreciendo a buenos precios de productos, resultado del traslado de los precios de oportunidad con el que Melida accede al mercado al comprarle en mayor cantidad.
texts.en:
Melida, 44, lives with her husband and four children whose ages range from 6 to 24 years in the city of Cartagena, located on the shores of the Caribbean Sea, one of Colombia’s best-known tourist sites because it has one of the country’s main naval bases and its historical-artistic heritage encompasses Carthaginian, Roman and Byzantine military styles from both modern and contemporary ages as well as neo-classical and modern buildings.

In that fantastic place in a modest way she runs her grocery, soft-drinks, beverage, snacks, foodstuffs and canned goods store.  She also sells stationery supplies, cosmetics and women’s accessories as well as other merchandise that sells well and complements the main products she retails increasing her income and helping her capital to turnover frequently.

When Melida decided to develop her enterprising, independent idea she did it after an experience she had with her husband.  They lost the jobs they had at a leather processing firm and decided to apply the useful skills they had in sales to start their own business venture and generate their own independent employment.  This is how the store started out because this couple wanted to generate sufficient income to benefit their family.

At first they sold just a few products adding more new ones every time until they attained the diversity they now have because they also offer merchandise via catalogue especially beauty products.  Her greatest challenge is not having sufficient capital to implement a marketing strategy that will allow her to impress with her prices, special promotions and products her customers constantly request and often are unavailable in stock thus leaving some demand unmet.

This is the reason why they are calling on a Kiva loan, the first financing they get from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo through which they will buy foodstuffs, groceries, meats, canned goods, dairy products and beauty products that are on special in her catalogue.  With this investment she plans to increase income offering products at good prices resulting from her passing down to her customers the special prices Melida gets by being able to buy in quantity.

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Libia Ines

texts.es:
Libia se encuentra casada y tiene 9 hijos a quienes siempre les ha querido brindar una buena calidad de vida y para esto tiene un negocio con el cual genera los ingresos para su hogar y contribuye económicamente junto con su esposo para que en su familia puedan tener una buena calidad de vida. Desde hace aproximadamente 25 años se vio desplazada por la violencia junto con su esposo y sus hijos en búsqueda de mejores oportunidades económicas para salir adelante y mayor seguridad para vivir más tranquilamente, y fue vendiendo gaseosas y dulces como comenzó con su propio negocio. Gracias al esfuerzo que ha puesto en su negocio logró salir adelante y cada vez aumentar más sus ventas, hasta el punto en que logró abrir otro local para vender bebidas y dulces el cual administra su esposo. Con su negocio ha podido brindarles educación a sus hijos y aún puede brindar educación a sus hijos menores, por esto siempre cuida de este y busca que cada vez sus ventas aumenten para tener una mejor calidad de vida. Libia busca un préstamo que le permita acceder a la compra de bebidas y otros productos para surtir su tienda y responder a la demanda de sus clientes.

De esta manera seguirá satisfaciendo las necesidades de sus clientes y sus ventas aumentarán considerablemente, permitiendo tener mejores ingresos para su hogar y así tener una mejor calidad de vida y mejores oportunidades económicas para progresar y salir adelante. Su mayor sueño es ver a todos sus hijos salir adelante y lograr darles una estabilidad económica con su negocio.
texts.en:
Libia is married and has 9 children, for whom she has always wanted to provide a good quality of life. For this she has a business by which income for her home is generated. Along with her husband she contributes economically so in her family they can have a good quality of life.  Approximately 25 years ago, she was displaced by violence along with her husband and their children. In search of better economic opportunities to get ahead and more security to live more tranquilly, she started selling soft drinks and candies and began her own business.  Thanks to the effort that she has put in her business, she was able to get ahead and increase her sales more each time, until the point in which she was able to open another location to sell drinks and sweets, which her husband manages.

With her business she has been able to provide education to her children and she can even provide education for her youngest children.  For this she always looks after her business and strives for her sales to increase each time to have a better quality of life.  Libia is looking for a loan that will allow her to buy drinks and other products to supply her store and respond to the demand of her customers.

In this way she will continue satisfying the needs of her customers and her sales will increase considerably, allowing her to have a better income for her home and like this have a better quality of life and better economic opportunities to progress and get ahead.  Her greatest dream is to see all of her children get ahead and to achieve giving them economic stability with her business.

loans.use: to buy drinks and other products to supply her store and respond to the demand of her customers.

loans.name: Francia

texts.es: Francia  con su credikiva anterior, compró insumos y materiales con los que fabricó bolsos, hamacas y hasta le alcanzó su dinero, para comprar una vitrina. En la actualidad está aplicando a un nuevo credikiva, con el cual comprará hilos y fabricará nuevas hamacas y bolsos,  aprovechando que muy pronto llega la época de vacaciones y sus clientes  al pasa para Cartagena, le compran las tradicionales artesanías de San Jacinto, producto de las manos de mujeres fieles a su tradición. Su mensaje a los financiadores de Kiva es el siguiente: “ Estoy muy agradecida con los préstamos y espero que me sigan apoyando para poder cumplir con el sueño de tener un local con amplia variedad de artesanías y vender mucho mas. “
texts.en:
Francia used her previous Kiva loan to buy supplies and materials she used to manufacture purses, hammocks and still had enough money to buy a display case.  She’s currently applying for a new Kiva loan she’ll use to buy thread to make new hammocks and purses taking advantage of the soon to arrive vacation season when customers on their way to Cartagena buy traditional San Jacinto crafts from her, products from the hands of women who preserve their traditions.

Her message to Kiva lenders is the following: “I am very grateful for the loans and I hope you will continue supporting me so that I can reach my dream of having a well-stocked crafts store and to sell much more.”

loans.use: to buy thread.

loans.name: Mayrlim

texts.es: Myrlim de 26 años de edad años de edad , vive con su cónyuge y su hijo de 10 meses en la ciudad de Cartagena, lugar ubicado a orillas del Mar Caribe, uno de los sitios turísticos mas hermosos de Colombia y muy reconocido, pues   tiene una de las principales bases navales del país y  por su patrimonio histórico-artístico, que abarca de vestigios de época cartaginesa, romana, bizantina, edificaciones de carácter militar de época moderna y contemporánea, así como también edificios neoclásicos y modernistas. Allí en este fantástico lugar y de manera modesta tiene sus dos  negocios uno de distribución de mercancía variada, como pantalones jeans y con el otro complementa sus ingresos, elaborando productos derivados de la harina de trigo o congelados, como empanadas, deditos de queso entre otros. Ella estudiaba educación infantil y cuando se organizó en familia y esperaba su primer hijo, debió retirarse de la universidad  y buscar una forma de generar ingresos, así fue como empezó su actividad de negociante de mercancía y aprovechó el saber de su suegra, quien la enseño a prepara congelados,  para apoyar el bienestar de su reciente hogar. Las mercancías variadas las venden a crédito y las ofrece a su clientela mediante guías especializadas de productos, pues se afilió a una empresa que le proporciona esta forma de hacer negocio y los deditos empanaditas y otros congelados los hace por encargos mediante una preventa a casa de eventos, familiares, vecinos y referidos de sus clientes. Su meta mas adelante,  es aumentar sus ingresos suficientemente para lograr adquirir su propia casa y planearle un futuro prometedor a su hijo.
